item.title: Qué significa ‘concise’
item.description: Esta palabra ha aparecido en 111 artículos en NYTimes.com en el último año. ¿Puedes usarla en una frase?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Word of the Day: concise
item.description: This word has appeared in 111 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Stephen Colbert Sizes Up R.F.K. Jr.’s Workout With Kid Rock
item.description: “The Late Show” host called the 90-second video of the two working up a sweat together “pure cinema.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: Bernie Sanders Urges Support of California Billionaire Tax at Los Angeles Rally
item.description: The senator from Vermont was the only elected leader at the event, which formally kicked off a health care union’s campaign to put the tax proposal on the ballot.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Rosenhall and Ryan Mac

media:content.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Senator Bernie Sanders, Independent of Vermont, speaks in Los Angeles on Wednesday in support of a proposed California ballot issue that would impose a tax on billionaires in the state.

media:content.media:credit: Jin Yu Young/The New York Times

item.title: Live Updates: South Korean Ex-Leader Is Sentenced to Life in Prison
item.description: Former President Yoon Suk Yeol, who was impeached after he briefly imposed martial law in 2024, had faced a potential death sentence in the country’s ​biggest criminal trial in decades.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Soo-Hyeon Kim/Reuters

item.title: Money Talks as India Searches for Its Place in Global A.I.
item.description: Narendra Modi, the prime minister, convened foreign leaders, the richest Silicon Valley companies and thousands of Indian entrepreneurs for a week of deal making.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Hari Kumar

media:content.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The India A.I. Impact Summit unfolded across 120 acres in New Delhi this week, featuring more than 300 exhibitors and 500 sessions. Organizers expected about 250,000 participants and visitors.

item.title: These Olympians Excel on Two Types of Tracks
item.description: Among elite athletes exists an even more exclusive club: people who compete at both the Summer and Winter Games. Many are sprinters who turn to bobsled.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight

media:content.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Salomé Kora, left, will compete for a Swiss two-woman bobsled team this week in Cortina d’Ampezzo, Italy.

item.title: Policy Flip-Flops Hurt the British Leader. Then Came a New Political Threat.
item.description: Already weakened by “U-turns” on his agenda, Prime Minister Keir Starmer faced calls to step down over appointing a close friend of Jeffrey Epstein as U.S. ambassador.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear

media:content.media:credit: Suzanne Plunkett/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain speaking at a community center in Welwyn Garden City, Britain, last week.

item.title: Russia Celebrated Him. Now He’s Accused of Having Troops Shoot Themselves.
item.description: A lieutenant colonel is on trial after being accused of skimming payments for battlefield injuries. He denies the specifics of Russia’s accusation but acknowledges engaging in a payouts scheme.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Ksenia Churmanova

media:content.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A recruitment poster in Moscow last year. The military has struggled to root out endemic corruption.

item.title: What To Know About the Trial of Yoon Suk Yeol, South Korea’s Ousted Leader
item.description: Former President Yoon Suk Yeol was sentenced to life imprisonment after being found guilty on Thursday of leading an insurrection with his short-lived imposition of martial law in 2024.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang

media:content.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Yoon Suk Yeol in Seoul in 2022.

item.title: Stock Slide and Slow Sales: What’s Happening in China’s E.V. Market?
item.description: Investors are selling shares of Chinese E.V. companies, concerned that intensifying competition and shorter production cycles mean the years of easy growth are over.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Krolik

media:content.media:credit: Andrea Verdelli for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The BYD stand at an auto show in Shanghai last year. BYD’s stock has fallen over 35 percent since its peak last May.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Veterans Who Protest ICE’s Operations View Crackdown Differently
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, February 18, 2026.

item.title: Sugar Bowl Academy Says Multiple Victims Were Tied to Its Ski Resort School
item.description: Sugar Bowl Academy, a ski-focused private school in the Sierra Nevada, said that multiple people on the fatal trek were connected to its program.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla, Sabrina Tavernise and Deb Wandell

media:content.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The trail to Castle Peak near Donner Pass. Eight backcountry skiers are confirmed dead from an avalanche in the Castle Peak area at Donner Pass.

item.title: Trump’s Order Aims to Boost Ingredient Used in Roundup
item.description: An executive order aimed at ramping up production of glyphosate set off alarms among supporters of Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

media:content.media:credit: Regis Duvignau/Reuters
media:content.media:description: The weedkiller Roundup, whose active ingredient is glyphosate, is used by farmers around the world.

media:content.media:credit: Jin Yu Young/The New York Times

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Feb. 19, 2026
item.description: Speak of the devil! It’s John Ewbank.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: Justice Dept. Lawyer Is Found in Contempt by Federal Judge
item.description: The ruling out of Minnesota marks a new level of judicial concern about the Trump administration’s lack of compliance with judges’ orders in immigration cases.
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz and Seamus Hughes

media:content.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Justice Department has admitted violations in cases involving immigrants’ challenging the legality of their detention.

item.title: Police Chief Hired to Help Lead N.Y.C. Hospital Patrols Abruptly Quits
item.description: The assistant chief, Jamiel Altaheri, resigned almost immediately after starting the job, after The New York Times asked about misconduct allegations while he was a police chief in Michigan.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer and Chelsia Rose Marcius
item.category: New York City Health and Hospitals Corp

item.title: Texas Congressman’s Aide Told Co-Worker of Affair Before Killing Herself
item.description: The co-worker, who no longer works for Representative Tony Gonzales, shared screenshots of the text exchange with The New York Times. Mr. Gonzales accused his Republican primary challenger of being behind the revelation.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman and Edgar Sandoval

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Representative Tony Gonzales in Washington this month.

item.title: What to Know About the Lake Tahoe Avalanche That Killed 8 Skiers
item.description: At least eight skiers were killed, California authorities said, after heavy snow pummeled the region.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka and Alexandra E. Petri

media:content.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A ski resort employee digging out a car near the Castle Peak trailhead.

item.title: Israel’s Actions Questioned at Security Council Meeting
item.description: Amid criticism over the board’s structure and broad mandate, the U.S. ambassador to the U.N. defended the board, saying “a new way” was needed to address the situation in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi

media:content.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Michael Waltz, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, at the Security Council last month. Mr. Waltz said President Trump’s Board of Peace planned to pledge $5 billion to the reconstruction and rehabilitation of Gaza.

item.title: How Mamdani’s Income and Property Tax Proposals Could Affect New Yorkers
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani has now proposed two options that called for raising taxes. Here’s a look at each proposal and the rationale and chances for each.
item.dc:creator: Sally Goldenberg, Dana Rubinstein and Grace Ashford

media:content.media:credit: Seth Wenig/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani has proposed raising the property tax rate in New York City as a “last-resort” option in case state officials do not raise taxes on high earners.

item.title: As Trump Weighs Possible Iran Strikes, U.S. Military Moves Into Place
item.description: President Trump has given no indication that he has made a decision about how to proceed, as diplomatic talks continue.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Ronen Bergman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Jonathan Klein/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: The U.S.S. Gerald R. Ford aircraft carrier, seen here in the North Sea last year, is making its way toward the Middle East.

item.title: Trump apuesta por la diplomacia sin diplomáticos
item.description: Las personas designadas por Trump para las gestiones diplomáticas hablan el lenguaje de los negociadores, y no dedican mucho tiempo a dar lecciones sobre derechos humanos o construcción de la democracia.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Anton Troianovski

media:content.media:credit: Nathan Howard para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Steve Witkoff y Jared Kushner en Israel en octubre pasado

item.title: The Worst Avalanches in Recent North American History
item.description: With at least eight people dead, Tuesday’s avalanche in California was one of the deadliest in the last five decades.
item.dc:creator: Camille Baker

media:content.media:credit: Paul Chiasson/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: The snow-filled gymnasium of the school in Kangiqsualujjuaq, Quebec, where nine people were killed in an avalanche during New Year’s Eve celebrations in 1999.

item.title: As ICE Buys Up Warehouses, Even Some Trump Voters Say No
item.description: The agency is ramping up arrests, but local pushback is complicating efforts to expand detention capacity and prevent overcrowding.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo, Hamed Aleaziz and Allison McCann

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Stacy Bradley, right, and Sarah Wellman in the parking lot of their cheerleading gym in Surprise, Ariz. The federal government plans to convert the warehouse at right into a detention center for immigrants.

item.title: Shipwreck Found at the Bottom of Lake Michigan After Nearly 150 Years
item.description: The steamer Lac La Belle, which was carrying passengers and cargo, sank in a storm in 1872. Eight people died when one of its lifeboats capsized.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Ali Watkins

item.title: Shutdowns Don’t Usually Stop Disaster Work. FEMA Just Made It Harder.
item.description: The agency canceled some travel to disaster sites, citing a partial government shutdown, according to emails sent to staff.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance

media:content.media:credit: Julia Demaree Nikhinson/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: The Federal Emergency Management Agency headquarters in Washington last month.

item.title: Satellite Feature on iPhone Allowed Skiers to Seek Help After Avalanche
item.description: The Emergency SOS feature on iPhones can send texts to emergency responders via satellite when there is no cell tower nearby.
item.dc:creator: Kalley Huang

item.title: Officials Violated Court Orders on Immigration in New Jersey, Justice Dept. Tells Judge
item.description: The violations stemmed from immigration cases. Judges across the country have expressed alarm about illegal transfers and missed deadlines.
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz, Zach Montague and Luis Ferré-Sadurní

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Protesters outside Delaney Hall detention center in Newark, N.J., in December.

item.title: What to Know About Blackbird Mountain Guides, Which Led Sierra Ski Trip
item.description: Blackbird Mountain Guides, which has locations around the world, also taught mountain safety classes.
item.dc:creator: Christina Morales

media:content.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A group of skiers in the Sierra Nevada backcountry near Lake Tahoe, Calif.

item.title: Bald Eagle, Marooned on Ice Chunk in Hudson, Is Rescued by Police
item.description: The authorities took the injured bird to a rehabilitation center in New Jersey, which is working to stabilize it to allow for further testing and treatment.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

item.title: Officers Rescue Injured Bald Eagle on the Hudson River
item.description: New York City police officers spotted a bald eagle in distress during a patrol on Tuesday morning along the Hudson River.
item.dc:creator: Cynthia Silva

item.title: Decoding the A.I. Beliefs of Anthropic and Its C.E.O., Dario Amodei
item.description: The company is at odds with the Pentagon over how its A.I. will be used. The conflict has its roots in the foundational plan for Anthropic.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The contract between Anthropic and the Pentagon, worth as much as $200 million, is at stake.

item.title: Texas Election Season Heats Up as Early Voting in Senate Primaries Begins
item.description: Both parties’ Senate primary races are kicking into high gear.

media:content.media:description: State Representative James Talarico.

item.title: Defense Department and Anthropic Square Off in Dispute Over A.I. Safety
item.description: How artificial intelligence will be used in future battlefields is an issue that has turned increasingly political and may put Anthropic in a bind.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Defense Department and Anthropic have been negotiating a contract over A.I. use by the Pentagon.

item.title: Muslims in Gaza Observe Ramadan Amid Fragile Cease-Fire Deal
item.description: Muslims in Gaza broke their fast for the start of Ramadan on Wednesday. The holy month began amid a fragile cease-fire deal between Israel and Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Mitssunaga

media:content.media:credit: Dawoud Abu Alkas/Reuters

item.title: After Activist’s Killing, Tensions Erupt Between France’s Far-Right and Far-Left
item.description: The beating death of Quentin Deranque has quickly become a flashpoint between the far right and far left as France prepares for local elections next month and presidential elections next year.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler

media:content.media:credit: Olivier Chassignole/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: An area near the site of the brawl in Lyon, France, that led to the beating death of Quentin Deranque, on Saturday.

item.title: An Avalanche Near Lake Tahoe Kills at Least 8
item.description: Also, Mark Zuckerberg takes the stand. Here's the latest at the end of Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Nevada County Sheriff’s Office, via Reuters
media:content.media:description: Members of a rescue team in Soda Springs, Calif., yesterday.

item.title: Kansas, Idaho, Utah, Oklahoma in New Push to Restrict Transgender Rights
item.description: In states that once focused mainly on health care and sports for transgender minors, debates now revolve around the validity of transgender identity.
item.dc:creator: Amy Harmon

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A demonstrator outside the U.S. Supreme Court as the court heard arguments last month concerning transgender athletes participating in girls sports.

item.title: Inside the Birthplace of Your Favorite Technology
item.description: How Bell Labs shaped cellphones, satellites, video calls and A.I. technology.
item.dc:creator: Steve Lohr, Jeanne Noonan DelMundo and Tina Zhou

item.title: Jo Ann Bass, Matriarch of Joe’s Stone Crab in Miami Beach, Dies at 94
item.description: For decades, she oversaw a money-gushing South Florida restaurant that has drawn celebrities like Frank Sinatra, Muhammad Ali and Madonna.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

item.title: Donald J. Trump International Airport? The President’s Company Trademarked It.
item.description: The Trump organization said the move was necessary to protect the brand as Florida prepares to rename an airport after the president.
item.dc:creator: Ben Protess

media:content.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A plane belonging to Donald J. Trump arrived at Palm Beach International Airport in 2023. Florida Republicans have advanced an effort to rename the airport “President Donald J. Trump International Airport.”

item.title: Daniel Radcliffe Doesn’t Want His Son to Know He Played Harry Potter. At Least Not Yet.
item.description: Daniel Radcliffe, who returns to Broadway in “Every Brilliant Thing,” shared how his love for the “The Simpsons” has endured over the years and he revealed which books he is reading to his son.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson, Chevaz Clarke, Daniel Fetherston, Luke Piotrowski, Jolie Ruben, Amanda Webster and Zebediah Smith

media:content.media:credit: Lucia Bell-Epstein for The New York Times

item.title: Workplace Inspections by OSHA Dropped Over a Six-Month Period of 2025
item.description: Labor advocates worry that the Trump administration is relaxing oversight of companies and increasing the potential for serious injuries and deaths.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan and Rebecca Davis O’Brien

media:content.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Trump administration has made efforts to roll back regulations for worker safety and protections, including plans to pull back a requirement that employers provide appropriate lighting at construction sites.

item.title: David Hays, 95, Dies; Top Broadway Designer and Theater of Deaf Founder
item.description: He created sets and lighting for dozens of productions, including “Long Day’s Journey Into Night,” and established a new art form with his theater of the deaf, combining sign and spoken language.
item.dc:creator: Howard Fishman

item.title: 8 Skiers Are Dead in Sierra Nevada Avalanche
item.description: A final missing skier was also presumed dead, the authorities said. Six survivors were rescued. The avalanche is the deadliest in modern California history.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
